results.title: Vaccination policy reactance: Predictors, consequences, and ...
results.snippet: Ending the COVID‑19 pandemic will require rapid large-scale uptake of vaccines against the disease. Mandating vaccination is discussed as a suitable strategy to increase uptake.

metatags.citation_title: Vaccination policy reactance: Predictors, consequences, and countermeasures
metatags.citation_reference: citation_journal_title=European Journal of Public Health; citation_title=Detrimental effects of introducing partial compulsory vaccination: Experimental evidence; citation_author=C Betsch; citation_author=R B\u00f6hm; citation_volume=26; citation_issue=3; citation_publication_date=2016; citation_firstpage=378; citation_lastpage=381; citation_doi=10.1093/eurpub/ckv154;
metatags.og:title: Vaccination policy reactance: Predictors, consequences, and countermeasures
metatags.citation_abstract: Ending the COVID‑19 pandemic will require rapid large-scale uptake of vaccines against the disease. Mandating vaccination is discussed as a suitable strategy to increase uptake. In a series of cross-sectional quota-representative surveys and two preregistered experiments conducted in Germany and the US (total N = 4629), we investigated (i) correlates of individual preferences for mandatory (vs voluntary) COVID‑19 vaccination policies; (ii) potential detrimental effects of mandatory policies; and (iii) interventions potentially counteracting them. Results indicate that reactance elicited by mandates can cause detrimental effects, such as decreasing the intention to vaccinate against influenza and adhere to COVID-19 related protective measures.
